column2: Dutch: Buitenzorg) is a city in the West Java province
column3: Indonesia. Located around 60 kilometers (37 mi) south of the national capital of Jakarta
column4: Bogor is the 6th largest city of Jakarta metropolitan area and the 14th nationwide. The city covers an area of 118.5 km2
column5: and it had a population of 950
column6: 334 at the 2010 Census; the latest official estimate (as at 2018) was 1
column11: as well as a mountain resort.

column2: the city served as the capital of Sunda Kingdom (Indonesian: Kerajaan Sunda) and was called Pakuan Pajajaran or Dayeuh Pakuan. During the Dutch colonial era
column3: it was named Buitenzorg (meaning "Without worries" in Dutch) and served as the summer residence of the Governor-General of Dutch East Indies.

column1: With several hundred thousand people living on an area of about 20 km2 (7.7 sq mi)
column2: the central part of Bogor is one of the world's most densely populated areas. The city has a presidential palace and a botanical garden (Indonesian: Kebun Raya Bogor) – one of the oldest and largest in the world. It bears the nickname "the Rain City" (Kota Hujan)
column3: because of frequent rain showers.  It nearly always rains even during the dry season.

column1: The first mention of a settlement at present Bogor dates to the 5th century when the area was part of Tarumanagara
column2: one of the earliest states in Indonesian history. After a series of defeats by the neighboring Srivijaya
column3: Tarumanagara was transformed into the Sunda Kingdom
column4: and in 669
column5: the capital of Sunda was built between two parallel rivers
column6: the Ciliwung and Cisadane. It was named Pakuan Pajajaran
column7: in old Sundanese meaning "a place between the parallel [rivers]"
column8: and became the predecessor of the modern Bogor.

column2: Pakuan Pajajaran became one of the largest cities in medieval Indonesia with a population reaching 48
column3: 000. The name Pajajaran was then used for the entire kingdom
column4: and the capital was simply called Pakuan. The chronicles of that time were written in Sanskrit
column5: which was the language used for official and religious purposes
column6: using the Pallava writing system
column7: on rock stellas called prasasti. The prasasti found in and around Bogor differ in shape and text style from other Indonesian prasasti and are among the main attractions of the city.In the 9–15th centuries
column8: the capital was moving between Pakuan and other cities of the kingdom
column9: and finally returned to Pakuan by King Siliwangi (Sri Baduga Maharaja) on 3 June 1482 – the day of his coronation. Since 1973
column10: this date is celebrated in Bogor as an official city holiday.In 1579
column11: Pakuan was captured and almost completely destroyed by the army of the Sultanate of Banten
column12: causing the existence of the State of Sunda to cease. The city was abandoned and remained uninhabited for decades.

column1: In the second half of the 17th century
column2: the abandoned Pakuan as most of West Java
column3: while formally remaining under the Sultanate of Banten
column4: gradually passed under control of the Dutch East India Company (VOC). The formal transition occurred on 17 April 1684 by signing an agreement between the Crown Prince of Banten and the VOC.The first
column5: and temporal
column6: colonial settlement at Pakuan was a camp of lieutenant Tanoejiwa
column7: a Sundanese employed by the VOC who was sent in 1687 to develop the area. It was seriously damaged by the eruption on 4–5 January 1699 of the Mount Salak volcano (Indonesian: Gunung Salak).  However
column8: the concomitant forest fires removed much forest
column9: leaving much area for the planned rice and coffee plantations. In a short time
column10: several agricultural settlements appeared around Pakuan
column11: the largest being Kampung Baru (lit. "new village").

column2: they were combined into an administrative district; Tanoejiwa was chosen as the head of the district and is regarded as the founder of the modern Bogor Regency.The district was further developed during the 1703 Dutch mission headed by the Inspector General of the VOC Abraham van Riebeeck (the son of the founder of Cape Town Jan van Riebeeck and later Governor of Dutch East Indies). The expedition of van Riebeeck performed a detailed study of the Pakuan ruins
column3: discovered and described many archaeological artifacts
column4: including prasasti
column5: and erected buildings for the VOC employees. The area attracted the Dutch by a favorable geographical position and mild climate
column6: preferred over the hot Batavia which was then the administrative center of the Dutch East Indies. In 1744–1745
column7: the residence of the Governor-General was built in Pakuan which was hosting the government during the summer.

column2: by the order of the Governor-General Gustaaf Willem van Imhoff
column3: the Palace
column4: a nearby Dutch settlement and nine native settlements were merged into an administrative division named Buitenzorg (Dutch for "beyond (or outside) concerns
column5: meaning without worries" or "carefree
column6: cf. Frederick the Great of Prussia's summer palace outside Potsdam, Sanssouci, with the same meaning in French.) Around the same time, the first reference to Bogor as the local name of the city was documented; it was mentioned in the administration report from 7 April 1752 with respect to the part of Buitenzorg adjacent to the Palace. Later this name became used for the whole city as the local alternative to Buitenzorg. This name is believed to originate from the Javanese word bogor meaning sugar palm (Arenga pinnata), which is still used in the Indonesian language. Alternative origins are the old-Javanese word bhagar (meaning cow), or simply the misspelling of Buitenzorg" by the local residents.The city grew rapidly in the late 18th – early 19th centuries. This growth was partly stimulated by the temporary occupation of the Dutch East Indies by the United Kingdom in 1811–1815 – the British landed on Java and other Sunda Islands to prevent their capture by Napoleonic France which then conquered the Netherlands. The head of the British administration Stamford Raffles moved the administrative center from Batavia to Buitenzorg and implemented new and more efficient management techniques.

column1: ==== Rule of the Kingdom of the Netherlands ====
After Buitenzorg was returned to the Dutch
column2: it fell under the rule of the Kingdom of the Netherlands rather than VOC. The Buitenzorg Palace was reinstated as the summer residence of the Governor-General. A botanical garden was set up nearby in 1817
column3: which was one of the world's largest gardens in the 19th century.

column2: Buitenzorg was seriously damaged by another eruption of the Salak volcanoes caused by an earthquake. Taking into account the seismic activity of the region
column3: the governor's palace and office buildings constructed in 1840–1850 were built shorter but sturdier than those built prior to the eruption. The Governor's decree of 1845 prescribed separate settlements of European
column4: Chinese and Arab migrants within the city.In 1860–1880
column5: the largest agricultural school in the colony was established in Buitenzorg. Other scientific institutions including a city library
column6: natural science museum
column7: biology
column9: and veterinary medicine laboratories were also constructed during this period. By the end of the 19th century
column10: Buitenzorg became one of the most developed and Westernized cities in Indonesia.In 1904
column11: Buitenzorg formally became the administrative center of the Dutch East Indies. However
column13: which hosted most of the administrative offices and the main office of the governor. This status was revoked in the administrative reform of 1924
column14: which divided the colony into provinces and set Buitenzorg as the center of West Java Province.

column2: Buitenzorg and the entire territory of Dutch East Indies were occupied by Japanese forces; the occupation lasted from 6 March 1942 until the summer of 1945. As part of the efforts by the Japanese to promote nationalist (and thus anti-Dutch) sentiments among the local population the city was given the Indonesian name Bogor. The city had one of the major training centres of the Indonesian militia PETA (Pembela Tanah Air – "Defenders of the Motherland").On 17 August 1945
column3: Sukarno and Hatta proclaimed independence
column4: but the Dutch regained control of the town and adjoining areas. In February 1948
column5: Buitenzorg was included in the quasi-independent state of West Java
column6: (Indonesian: Negara Jawa Barat) which was renamed Pasundan in April 1948 (Indonesian: Negara Pasundan). This state was established by the Netherlands as a step to transform their former colonial possessions in the East Indies into a dependent federation. In December 1949
column7: Pasundan joined the Republic of the United States of Indonesia (Indonesian: Republik Indonesia Serikat
column8: RIS) established at the Dutch–Indonesian Round Table Conference of 23 August – 2 November 1949. In February 1950
column9: as a result of defeat of Pasundan in a quick military conflict with the Republic of Indonesia
column10: the city became part of Indonesia
column12: and its name was officially declared as Bogor.

column2: Bogor has a significant role in the cultural
column3: scientific and economic development of the country and West Java in particular – in part due to the legacy of infrastructure built during the colonial period. Its special position was further reinforced by the transformation of the former summer residence of the governor-general into the summer palace of the President of Indonesia. In the 1990s–2000s
column4: the city regularly hosted various international events
column5: such as ministry-level meetings of the Asia-Pacific institutions and the APEC summit of 15 November 1994. Since 2008
column6: a Christian church congregation in Bogor has been embroiled with Islamic fundamentalists over the building permit for their new church.

column1: The city is situated in the western part of Java island
column2: about 53 km south of the capital Jakarta and 85 km northwest of Bandung
column3: the administrative center of West Java Province. Bogor spreads over a basin near volcanoes Salak
column4: which peaks at about 12 km south
column5: and Mount Gede whose top is 22–25 km south-east of the city. The average elevation is 265 meters
column6: maximum 330 m
column7: and minimum 190 meters above sea level. The terrain is rather uneven: 17.64 km2 of its area has slopes of 0–2°
column10: 7.65 km2 from 25° to 40° and 1.20 km2 over 40°; the northern part is relatively flat and the southern part is more hilly.The soils are dominated by volcanic sedimentary rocks. Given the proximity of large active volcanoes
column11: the area is considered highly seismic. The total area of green space is 205
column19: 400 m2 are covered with grass.Several rivers flow through the city toward the Java Sea. The largest ones
column21: flank the historic city center. Smaller rivers
column25: are guided by cement tubes in many places. It is worth noting that "ci" in the river names merely means "river" in Sundanese
column26: and the actual name begins after it
column27: but the "ci" is nevertheless included into national and international maps. There are several small lakes within the city
column28: including Situ Burung (lit. Bird Lake; "Situ" meaning "Lake") and Situ Gede (lit. Great Lake)
column29: with the area of several hectares each. Rivers and lakes occupy 2.89% of the city area.

column1: Bogor has a tropical rainforest climate (Af) according to the Köppen climate classification
column2: and more humid and rainy than in many other areas of West Java – the average relative humidity is 70%
column3: the average annual precipitation is about 1700 mm
column4: but more than 3500 mm in some areas. Most rain falls between December and February. Because of this weather
column5: Bogor has the nickname "Rain City" (Indonesian: Kota hujan). The temperatures are lower than in coastal Java: the average maximum is 25.9 °C (cf. 32.2 °C in Jakarta). Daily fluctuations (9–10 °C) are rather high for Indonesia. The absolute maximum temperature was recorded at 38 °C and the minimum at 3 °C.

column1: The rapid population growth in Bogor after 1960 is related to urbanization as well as the influx of workforce from other parts of the country. The birth rate in 2009 was 563 children per 10
column2: 000 people
column3: with the mortality value of 272. During the same year
column5: 709 permanent resident moved in and 3
column6: 391 people left the city. Men constituted 51.06% and women 48.94% of the population; 28.39% of the inhabitants were under 15 years old
column7: 67.42% were aged 15–65 years and 3.51% – over 65 years. The 2005 estimate of the life expectancy is 71.8 years
column8: which is the highest figure for West Java and one of the highest in Indonesia.Most population (87%) are Sundanese
column12: often mixed ethnicities. Virtually all adults are fluent in Indonesian – the official language of the country. Sundanese is used at home and in some public areas and events – for example
column13: the solemn speech of the mayor at the City Day celebration of 3 June 2010 was delivered in Sundanese. The local dialect of Sundanese significantly differs from the classical version both lexically and phonetically.The majority of population (94%) are Muslims
column15: there are many Christian churches in the city
column16: as well as Buddhist (mostly in the Chinese community) and Hindu communities.

column1: Bogor City is surrounded by the Bogor Regency (kabupaten) but in itself is a separate municipality (kota)
column2: making Bogor City an enclave within Bogor Regency. The city is divided into six districts (kecamatan)
column3: which contain 68 low-level administrative units
column4: 31 of which have the status of urban settlements and 37 are rural villages.

column1: The city is headed by a mayor
column2: who is elected by the citizens every five years
column3: together with a vice-mayor; in the past
column4: the mayor was appointed by the provincial administration. Diani Budiarto became the first directly elected mayor of Bogor on 25 October 2008 and assumed his position on 7 April 2009. Legislative power is provided by the City Council which consists of 45 people's representatives who are also elected by the residents for a 5-year term. Nine political parties consisting of five factions are represented in the Council.The coat of arms of Bogor is a rectangular heraldic shield with a pointed base and the side lengths ratio of 5:4
column5: divided by a cross into four parts. The upper left quarter contains the National emblem of Indonesia – the mythical bird Garuda
column6: in the upper right is the presidential palace
column7: in the bottom left is the Salak volcano
column8: and in the lower right is the national Sundanese dagger kujang. The inscription on top reads "KOTA BOGOR" which translates to "THE CITY OF BOGOR".

column1: Bogor has developed automotive chemical and food industries; its outlying areas are used for agriculture. During the colonization
column2: Bogor was mostly producing coffee
column3: rubber and high-quality timber. Chemical industry was introduced to the city at the end of the 19th century
column4: and car and metal production in the 1950s

column1: Bogor is one of the major scientific and educational centers in Indonesia. A significant part of academic and research base was laid in the period of Dutch colonization. In particular
column2: since the beginning of the 19th century there were established laboratories and professional schools focused primarily on improving the efficiency of the colonial agricultural; In the late 19th – early 20th centuries have been established over major scientific institutions – the Research Institute and Rubber Research Institute of Forest.Similar to the prevailing profile of research and academic activity was retained in Bogor Indonesia and after gaining independence. As in the second half of 20th century
column3: and in the 2000s strongest areas were agricultural science
column4: Biology and Veterinary. The main educational and scientific center with the utmost national importance
column5: is IPB University
column6: which structure
column7: in addition to educational facilities
column8: includes dozens of research centers and laboratories.Bogor hosts the global headquarters of the Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR)
column9: an international organization conducting research on forestry and human development.  The headquarters of the Organisation for the Preservation of Birds and their Habitat are also in Bogor.

column1: Bogor is one of the leading cities of Indonesia by the number of museums

Other prominent musea are more recent. So the museum of ethnobotany (Indonesian: Museum Etnobotani) was opened in 1982 and has more than 2000 exhibits; museum of the earth (Indonesian: Museum Tanah

column3: of whom more than 60
column4: 000 are foreigners. The main tourist attraction is the Bogor Botanical Garden. Founded in 1817

column6: 000 species of tropical plants. Besides

Much of the original rainforest was preserved within the garden providing specimens for scientific studies. Besides

column1: It became famous in the late 19th century and was visited by naturalists from abroad to conduct scientific research. For example
column2: the Russian St. Petersburg Academy of Sciences had a Buitenzorg scholarship for young scientists to work at Bogor. The staff of Bogor garden also administer three other major gardens of Iindonesia: the Cibodas Botanical Garden founded 1862 in West Java
column3: the Purwodadi Botanical Garden in East Java and the Bali Botanic Garden founded in 1959 on Bali island.

column1: Another tourist attraction is the presidential palace with the total area of 28 hectares
column2: including 1.8492 hectares of the palace buildings. The palace is surrounded by a park with a small pond. The park is home to a herd of tame deer and is open to the public most of the year. The palace is accessible during holidays
column3: such as the City Day and Independence Day; it has a collection of 450 paintings and 360 sculptures.The city and its suburbs contain dozens of medieval stone stelae (prasasti). Fifteen prasasti of the greatest historical and cultural value are collected in a special pavilion in the district of Batutulis. In the western part of Bogor there is a large lake Gede (area 6 hectares) surrounded by the reserved forest area and a forest park. In the protected area there are several research facilities
column4: and the recreation areas host sports activities
column5: boating and fishing.On the territory of the botanic garden

column14: and the Buddhist temple Hok Tek Bio

This bus is called UNCAL which means "Unforgettable City Tour at Lovable City".
